questions.question: What is the pinna made up of?
questions.explanation: The pinna, also known as the auricle, is primarily made up of auricular cartilage.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman undergoes a rhinoplasty procedure to correct a deformity of her nose. Auricular cartilage is harvested from her right pinna. Which of the following sites cannot be used to harvest the cartilage?
questions.explanation: Incisura terminalis cannot be used to harvest cartilage as it is devoid of cartilage. It is the part of the pinna between the tragus and the crus of helix. Being devoid of cartilage, the incision for endaural approach for ear surgery can be made here. The lobule is also devoid of cartilage. Hence, it is the safest site for piercing. The parts of the pinna are: Helix, Antihelix, Concha, Antitragus, Triangular fossa, Incisura terminalis, External acoustic meatus, Tragus, and Lobule.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the skin over the pinna?

options.A: Firmly adherent on the medial side
options.B: Loosely adherent on the medial side

questions.explanation: The skin over the pinna is loosely adherent on the medial or cranial side; hence, it is pinchable. The skin is firmly adherent to the perichondrium on the lateral side and is non-pinchable.

questions.question: What is the length of the external auditory canal?
questions.explanation:
The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm. It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts: 
      • Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
      • Inner bony part - 16mm. 
      The external acoustic meatus, also known as the ear canal, is composed of these parts: 
      Auricle, External acoustic meatus, Tympanic membrane, Bone (medial - 16mm), Cartilage (lateral - 8mm).

questions.question: You are an intern asked to do an otoscopic examination of a young adult. In which direction will you pull the pinna to visualize the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation: The pinna has to be pulled upwards, backwards, and laterally to visualize the tympanic membrane. This is done to bring the bony and cartilaginous parts of the external auditory canal in alignment. The inner bony part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially. The outer cartilaginous part is directed upwards, backwards, and laterally.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the external auditory canal?

options.A: Outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 2/3rd is bony
options.B: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony
options.C: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous
options.D: Outer 2/3rd is bony and inner 1/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.explanation: The outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous (8mm) and the inner 2/3rd is bony (16mm) in the external auditory canal. Auricle External acoustic meatus Tympanic membrane Bone (medial-16mm) Cartilage (lateral-8mm)

questions.question: A patient with otitis externa develops parotitis. You suspect that the infection has spread through the fissures of Santorini. Which of the following best describes this fissure?

options.B: Connection between the middle ear and pharynx
options.C: Connection between the inner ear and middle ear

questions.explanation: Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the canal or vice versa. The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke, which acts as a pathway for the spread of infections and tumors to the deep lobe of the parotid.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the external auditory canal?

options.A: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony part
options.B: Furuncles are seen in the cartilaginous part
options.C: Fissures of Santorini are present in the bony part and permit parotid and superficial mastoid infections to spread to the canal
options.D: Isthmus is present at the junction of the cartilaginous and bony part

questions.explanation: Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the canal since hair is confined to the outer canal. The skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.

questions.question: What are ceruminous glands?
questions.explanation: Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles and participate in wax production. Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted. Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll's glands, and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the isthmus?

options.A: It is just lateral to the petrotympanic suture.
options.B: It is at the bony cartilaginous junction of the EAC.
options.C: It is the narrowest part of the ear canal.

questions.explanation: The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal (EAC). The EAC measures about 24 mm long; the cartilaginous part forms the outer one-third (8 mm), and the bony part forms two-thirds (16 mm) of the canal. The isthmus is situated 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane in the bony part of the EAC. Foreign bodies that go beyond the isthmus are difficult to remove and are called impacted.

questions.question: You observe a normal-looking tympanic membrane on otoscopy. What is its color?
questions.explanation: The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tympanic membrane?

options.B: It is derived from all 3 germ layers
options.C: It separates external from middle ear

questions.explanation: Peripheral parts are more mobile than the central part where the handle of the malleus is attached. The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers. It has 3 layers - Outer epithelial layer from ectoderm, Middle fibrous layer from mesoderm, Inner mucosal layer from endoderm.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation: The tympanic membrane has a thickness of 0.1 mm. The dimensions of the tympanic membrane are: Length: 9-10 mm, Width: 8-9 mm, Area: 90 mm^2. It subtends an angle of 55° with the horizontal. The medial (inner) surface is convex and the lateral surface is concave. The most depressed part of its concavity is called the umbo, to which the tip of the malleus is attached.

questions.question: What is the other name for Shrapnell's membrane?
questions.explanation: Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell's membrane. Pars flaccida is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

questions.question: During an otoscopic examination of a patient, where will the cone of light be seen on the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation: A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the tip of the malleus (umbo) to the periphery in the antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. The posterior malleal fold, tympanic membrane, pars flaccida, and other structures are related to this, with the cone of light specifically noted in the antero-inferior quadrant.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves supply a major part of the pinna?
questions.explanation: Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) supplies most of the medial surface and posterior portion of the lateral surface of the external ear. Nerve Derivation: Greater/Great auricular nerve - Cervical plexus C2, C3; Lesser occipital nerve - Cervical plexus C2, C2, C3. Region supplied: Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface; Superior portion of medial surface. Nerve: Auricular branch. Derivation: Vagus (X); Auriculotemporal nerve - Mandibular (V3); Facial (VII). Nerve supply of pinna: Lesser occipital nerve (C2) - Concha and antihelix; Some supply medial surface (eminencia concha); Tragus, crus of helix, and adjacent helix; Small region in the root of concha and retroauricular groove. Auriculotemporal nerve (V3); Great auricular nerve (C2, 3); Great auricular nerve (C2, 3); CN VII and X; CN VII and X.

questions.question: A patient develops tingling and numbness along the upper part of the medial surface of the pinna. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
questions.explanation: The upper part of the medial surface of the pinna is supplied by the lesser occipital nerve. Derivation: Nerve - Greater/Great auricular nerve: Cervical plexus C2, C3; Lesser occipital nerve: Auricular branch, Vagus (X), Cervical plexus C2; Auriculotemporal nerve: Mandibular (V3), Facial (VII). Region supplied: Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface, Superior portion of medial surface, Concha and antihelix, Some supply medial surface (eminetia concha), Tragus, crus of helix and adjacent helix, Small region in the root of concha and retroauricular groove. Nerve supply of pinna: Auriculotemporal, Lesser occipital nerve (C2), Great auricular nerve (C2, 3), CN VII and X.

questions.question: A patient coughs when removing excess cerumen from the ear. This is due to the stimulation of which of the following nerves?
questions.explanation: Reflex cough is due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus. It can occur when cleaning or during an examination of the ear. Nerve Derivation: Greater/Great auricular nerve - Cervical plexus C2, C3; Lesser occipital nerve; Auricular branch - Vagus (X) - Cervical plexus C2; Auriculotemporal nerve - Mandibular (V3); Facial (VII). Region supplied: Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface; Superior portion of medial surface; Concha and antihelix; Some supply medial surface (eminetia concha); Tragus, crus of helix and adjacent helix; Small region in the root of concha and retroauricular groove.

questions.question: What is Arnold's nerve?
questions.explanation: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) is also called Arnold's nerve or Alderman's nerve. Tympanic branch of CN IX is also called Jacobson's nerve. Sensory root of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg and carries secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland and salivary glands, and brings fibers of taste and general sensation.

questions.question: Which of the following cranial nerves do not supply the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) does not supply the tympanic membrane. It is supplied by: the lateral surface - the anterior half by the auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3) and the posterior half by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X), and the medial surface - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's nerve) CN IX.

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents with bleeding from his ear following a road traffic accident. Which of the following could be its reason?
questions.explanation: A temporal bone fracture can cause bleeding from the ear as it is related to the roof of the middle ear and the external auditory canal. The relations of the external auditory canal are: • Superior: Middle cranial fossa • Inferior: Parotid gland • Anterior: Temporomandibular joint • Posterior: Mastoid air cells and facial nerve.

questions.question: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.explanation: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve). Arnold's nerve supplies the concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface. It also supplies the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal. Scratching or mechanical stimulation of the ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough (ear-cough reflex/otorespiratory reflex). The image below shows the nerve supply of the pinna: Causes of referred otalgia - Temporomandibular joint and dental conditions, parotid infections/tumors, and anterior 2/3rd of tongue. Nerve responsible - Site: Auriculotemporal nerve - Tragal area, crus of the helix, and anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal. Causes of referred otalgia - Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, carcinoma base of the tongue or tonsils (oropharynx), carcinoma of the larynx (cough), hypopharynx, epiglottis, vallecula, esophagus, and thyroid; Cervical spondylitis; Acoustic neuroma. Nerve responsible - The glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's) - Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's/Alderman's nerve) - Great auricular nerve (C2,3) - Facial nerve (nervus intermedius/nerve of Wrisberg). Site - Medial surface of the tympanic membrane, and middle ear - Concha, posterior wall, and floor of the external auditory canal - Lateral and medial surfaces of the pinna - Concha, retroauricular groove, and posterosuperior part of the external auditory meatus. Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall, known as Hitzelberger's sign, is seen in acoustic neuroma. Nerve supply of pinna - Auriculotemporal nerve (V3) - Lesser occipital nerve (C2) - Great auricular nerve (C2,3) - CN VII and X.
